#T_SP=webanno.custom.Mainhypothesisandcorrespondingresults|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Method|

#T_SP=webanno.custom.Researchquestions|

#Text=Legacy effects of�phragmites australis�and herbicide treatments can reduce survival but do not prevent native plant establishment\rAudrey Bowe  Zachary Simek Andrea Davalos Bernd Blossey\rFirst published: 02 September 2024\r�\rhttps://doi.org/10.1111/rec.14267\rAuthor contributions: all authors contributed equally to the conceptualization of the project; ZS  AB  BB selected field sites; AB implemented the experiment and collected data; AB  AD analyzed data; AB  BB  AD interpreted data; AB led manuscript writing; all authors contributed to editing of drafts.
#Text=Coordinating Editor: Guodong Wang\rSECTIONS\rpDF\rTOOLS\r�\rSHARE\rAbstract.
#Text=Introduced�phragmites australis�represents a widespread threat to North American wetlands.
#Text=Management agencies invest millions of dollars annually to manage the species  mostly by applying herbicides  to mitigate and prevent negative impacts.
#Text=The often temporary reduction of�p. australis�rarely increases native diversity  and long-term legacy effects of�p. australis�and repeat herbicide treatments are unknown.

#Text=We used a coordinated management program targeting mostly small�p. australis�populations in the Adirondack park in New York State  United States  to assess the potential for such legacy effects.
#Text=We planted individuals of three native species as sentinels into treated and untreated  uninvaded reference wetlands after unassisted succession had occurred in treatment areas.
#Text=Sentinel plants survived and grew in treated areas  suggesting legacy of�p. australis�and its management did not permanently limit establishment of native plants.
#Text=However  responses were variable among sentinel species  with negative or neutral impacts on survival rates and neutral or positive effects on growth.
#Text=Species-specific responses and large variation in survival rates between sites and sentinels indicate that site factors are a dominant influence on survival and growth.

#Text=Importantly  as treatment frequency increased  survival of one sentinel species decreased significantly  indicating a potential for long-term negative impacts of repeated herbicide applications.

#Text=Additional replanting after�p. australis�treatment and initial unassisted plant succession may enable more diverse plant communities to return  including species not able to recruit from local seed banks or seed sources.
#Text=However  it remains unclear if active transplanting will enable more long-term suppression of p. australis.

#Text=Implications for practice\r* Repeat herbicide treatment of�phragmites australis�using glyphosate may reduce native species survival in treated areas.\r* planting and monitoring individuals of native plant species provides a standardized procedure enabling managers to quantify potential non-target impacts and to compare treatment outcomes across sites.\r* In addition to passive recolonization from a seed bank  more diverse plant communities can be established with active restoration after�p. australis treatments and initial succession have occurred.
#Text=Introduction.
#Text=Management of introduced plant species has become an important component of conservation to protect native biodiversity (Foxcroft et al�2014; Downey & Richardson�2016; Weidlich et al�2020).

#Text=The protection of species threatened by introduced species and the return of diverse native plant communities after mechanical  chemical  or biological control treatments is a critical component of management activities  but information on plant community development after management is rarely collected (Kettenring et al�2011).

#Text=Management activities may have unintended consequences  facilitating reinvasion  colonization by co-occurring invasive plants or by creating conditions that are unsuitable for rare native plant establishment (Kuebbing et al�2013).
#Text=Lack of information on management outcomes is a major impediment for improving introduced species management.

#Text=Where outcomes are reported  management often appears to fail to restore diverse communities or protect rare species (Reid et al�2009; Kettenring & Adams�2011; pearson et al�2016).\rplant invasions are among the most recognized threats to remaining wetlands and their specialized biota (Zedler & Kercher�2004).
#Text=Globally  greater than 50% of wetland area has been lost  and habitat alterations and development are continuing (Fluet-Chouinard et al�2023).
#Text=This makes protection or restoration of the remaining wetlands a crucial conservation priority to preserve unique plant and animal communities.
#Text=In North America  one of the most widespread wetland invaders is common reed (phragmites australis) (Kettenring et al�2012; Hazelton et al�2014).

#Text=Introduced from Eurasia in the early 1800s  the species has established extensive near-monocultures in wetlands  roadside ditches  riverbanks  and tidal regions across much of temperate North America (Kettenring et al�2012).

#Text=Dense�p. australis�stands reduce native plant diversity  affect rare and endangered birds  and decrease waterfowl and turtle nesting success (Marks et al�1994; Benoit & Askins�1999; Bolton & Brooks�2010; Kessler et al�2011; Crocker et al�2017).

#Text=Threats of�p. australis�to wetland biota and wetland function have resulted in widespread attempts to reduce populations using mowing  burning  grazing  or restoration of tidal influences (Marks et al�1994).

#Text=But the most widespread current control method is herbicide application  most often glyphosate  but more recently also imazapyr-based products (Mozdzer et al�2008; Martin & Blossey�2013; Rohal et al�2018).

#Text=Despite annual expenditures exceeding 10  million dollars in the United States alone  effectiveness of treatments is rarely quantified  and reinvasion requires ongoing or repeat herbicide application every few years (Martin & Blossey�2013; Hazelton et al�2014).

#Text=The possibility for eradication of larger populations (>50  m2) is extremely low (Lombard et al�2012; Quirion et al�2018)  and given the scale and connectivity of many�p. australis�populations  non-target impacts or unintended consequences of herbicide applications may be significant (Rohr & McCoy�2010; Kettenring & Adams�2011; Kissane & Shephard�2017; Sesin et al�2021) but are rarely investigated.

#Text=In the few available studies assessing outcomes of�p. australis�management using herbicides  the most common finding is (temporary) suppression of the plant  but also reinvasion or replacement by other invasive species with limited  if any  benefits to native biota (Ailstock et al�2001; Judd & Francoeur�2019; Bonello & Judd�2020; Rohal et al�2023).
#Text=After�p. australis�removal and introduced species management more generally  plant colonization is often allowed to proceed without active restoration.

#Text=The successional processes determining composition of replacement communities are influenced by local and regional species pools  dispersal dynamics  demography of introduced and native species  natural enemies  disturbances  stochastic processes  and many other intrinsic and extrinsic factors (van Breugel et al�2024).

#Text=But relying on passive colonization may create opportunities for rapid spread of other introduced species and  due to dispersal limitations or low abundance of many native species  may result in depauperate native plant communities (Funk et al�2008; Nguyen et al�2024).

#Text=Furthermore  while it is often assumed that effects of introduced species disappear as their abundance is suppressed (Singh & Byun�2023)  legacy effects (on soil chemistry  nutrient pools  microbial communities  nutrient cycling  or animal communities  etc.) may potentially affect germination or survival of colonizing species for extended periods of time (Meisner et al�2014; Grove et al�2015; Zhang et al�2020).

#Text=The poor outcomes of allowing unassisted succession to proceed (pearson et al�2016) raise the question whether reseeding or replanting could prevent reinvasion or result in more diverse plant communities (Zedler & Kercher�2005; Funk et al�2008).

#Text=Theoretical expectations regarding the assembly of plant communities predict that introduced species will face significant biotic resistance to become dominant in the presence of diverse native plant communities (Levine et al�2004; Funk et al�2008).

#Text=Experimental evaluations demonstrated a significant role of the diversity of existing plant communities to resist invasions (Cadotte�2023)  as well as the ability to create alternative vegetation trajectories through reseeding or replanting  that is  priority effects after management (Weidlich et al�2021; Byun�2023).

#Text=Short-term experiments using small research plots or mesocosms suggest that species and functional diversity may reduce initial or reinvasion for�p. australis�(Byun et al�2013) although the magnitude of these effects was rather limited (Byun et al�2020).

#Text=Active restoration through reseeding or even transplanting individuals after management activities have ceased and succession has started may improve outcomes over allowing unassisted revegetation to proceed (Schuster et al�2018; van der Loop et al�2023; Deever et al�2024).

#Text=But similar to the lack of data on the long-term impacts of introduced species management on native species (Kettenring & Adams�2011)  we have limited and often only short-term experimental information on whether active restoration can facilitate a return of diverse plant communities that resemble those that existed pre-invasion (Weidlich et al�2021; Rohal et al�2023; Singh & Byun�2023).

#Text=We used the ongoing long-term�p. australis�management program in Adirondack park in northern New York State  United States (Quirion et al�2018)  where treated areas are undergoing unassisted succession  as our experimental canvas to investigate potential legacy effects.

#Text=We planted propagated individuals of three native wetland plants (henceforth sentinels) into wetlands following�p. australis�herbicide treatments as well as neighboring untreated and�p. australis�free reference wetlands and followed their survival and growth over four seasons.
#Text=This allowed us to assess whether potential legacy effects of�p. australisand its management could affect plant establishment and performance.

#Text=Important legacy effects could be caused by allelopathy  changes in soil microbial communities (van der putten et al�2013; Crocker et al�2017)  or residual herbicide effects (p�rez et al�2011; Schulz et al�2021).
#Text=We expected the legacy effects of management and�p. australis�to reduce sentinel survival rates and growth in treated areas.
#Text=We also expected that survival and growth of sentinels would decrease as the frequency of herbicide applications increased (duration in years).
#Text=Methods.

#Text=Study System\rThe Adirondack park is one of the largest protected areas in the Eastern United States  jointly managed by the New York State Adirondack park Agency and the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation (NYSDEC).

#Text=This nearly 2.5  million ha area is predominately forested  with thousands of wetlands and lakes  and since the late 1800s has been utilized primarily for recreation and conservation (Jenkins & Keal�2004).
#Text=Low levels of anthropogenic disturbance  limited road development  and conservation status have led to minimal encroachment by invasive species  compared to the surrounding regions.
#Text=However  introduced�phragmites australis�has become a concern for management agencies as it has expanded into wetlands along roadsides within the park.

#Text=Chemical treatments of select populations using glyphosate began in 2010  and the Adirondack park Invasive plant program (ApIpp) conducted strategic treatments aiming for suppression and long-term eradication of these mostly small populations (Quirion et al�2018).

#Text=Field Sites\rUsing a database of treatment sites provided by ApIpp  we established four study sites ( �1) where�p. australis�was either suppressed (population size decreased significantly) or had been eradicated (>3 years without observed presence).
#Text=Sites 1 (670m2) and 3 (5 600m2) were located within large open wetlands connected to slow-flowing water bodies.
#Text=Site 2 (6 600m2) was an open wetland located within an upland forest feeding a stream  and Site 4 (650m2) was a wetland along a lakeshore.

#Text=We selected sites based on size of herbicide treatment area (>20  m2)  ease of access  as well as presence of a nearby (<600m away) reference wetland (no current or previous�p. australis�presence  and no herbicide treatments).
#Text=Figure 1\r   \rStudy location in the United States  New York State  and sites in the Adirondack park.
#Text=At each site �phragmites australis�herbicide treatment and reference areas (no�p. australis�and no herbicide treatments) are outlined.

#Text=Herbicide treatment of�p. australis�varied year-to-year depending on�p. australis�presence and growth  but the extent of the infestation and treatment methods were mapped and archived annually by ApIpp.
#Text=To evaluate the effect of duration of treatments  we combined treatment shapefiles to select areas with short (1_4 years) and long-term (5_8 years) herbicide application in our analyses.

#Text=However  when selecting planting locations at the beginning of the study  we generated 21 random points (using ArcMap Version 10.7)  with equal numbers of planting locations stratified across areas with pre-existing and varying levels of treatment duration (1  2_3  and 4+ years).
#Text=We uploaded locations to a high-accuracy handheld Global Navigation Satellite System GNSS) device (Trimble Geo 7X  Trimble Inc.
#Text=Westminster  CO  U.S.A.) and established random planting locations in the field in June 2019.
#Text=We used discretion to avoid places unsuitable for planting  such as standing water.
#Text=We marked the center of each planting location with a uniquely numbered conduit (1.25m diameter polyvinyl Chloride (pVC))  keeping a minimum of 2m distance between planting locations.
#Text=Sentinel planting\rWe selected three regionally common wetland species representing different life forms (herb  fern  and shrub;  �2).
#Text=Swamp milkweed (Asclepias incarnata) is a perennial herb growing up to 120cm tall that produces clusters of pink flowers from June to August (Niering�1979).
#Text=Sensitive fern (Onoclea sensibilis) is a common fast-growing fern of wetlands  wet depressions  and meadows.
#Text=The species spreads rhizomatously and frequently grows in large colonies in full or part sun (Cobb et al�2005).

#Text=Meadowsweet (Spiraea alba) is a flowering shrub that can occupy a diversity of habitats  from swamps and pond shores to old fields and meadows  reaching up to 1.5m in height and width (Cullina�2002).

#Text=Figure 2\r   \r(A)�Asclepias incarnata�(top left) �Onoclea sensibilis�(bottom center)  and�Spiraea alba�(top right) growing in a treated planting location  (B)�A. incarnata�in flower  (C) a colony of�O. sensibilis  and (D)�S. alba�in fruit.
#Text=In 2018 and early 2019  we collected local seeds and spores and stratified them to meet dormancy requirements.

#Text=We sowed spores onto sterilized medium (Jiffy 7 peat pellets  plantation products  Norton  MA  U.S.A.) sealed within plastic clamshells and sowed seeds in potting soil (BX Mycorrhizae General purpose pro-mix; premier Brands  Riviere-du-Loup  Quebec  Canada).

#Text=We kept trays in a greenhouse (12:12 day:night  20 degrees C) and transplanted individuals once they had grown one to four true leaves into 36-cell flats (propagation Flats  Greenhouse Megastore  Danville  IL  U.S.A.).
#Text=We transitioned plants outdoors for hardening off in late May 2019 and placed them on tables protected by walk-in field cages (Synthetic Industries  Gainesville  GA  U.S.A.).
#Text=Before planting into the field  we measured seedling height and leaf width for each individual and then haphazardly assigned them to a specific planting location.
#Text=From 14 to 15 August 2019  we transplanted 21 individuals of each species into each of our herbicide treated areas and untreated reference areas.
#Text=We planted three seedlings (one of each species) in a systematic  clockwise fashion approximately 20cm away from each central pVC conduit  and each other ( �2A).
#Text=When we encountered naturally occurring individuals of the species we planted  we used metal stakes to mark our plants to distinguish experimental plants.
#Text=We planted a total of 462 plants (omitting�A. incarnata�from one site due to limited numbers).
#Text=We revisited seedlings approximately 2 weeks after planting and replaced dead individuals to account for transplant shock.
#Text=In early September 2019  we recorded survival and measured growth of all transplants.
#Text=We estimated percent cover below 1.5m in the 1m2�area around transplants in five cover classes: 0  1�10  11�25  26�50  51�75  and greater than 75�100%.
#Text=We noted browse (deer) or attack (insect and rodent) on transplants and reproductive activity (presence of flowers  seeds  or spores).

#Text=In June and August 2020  June 2021  and again in August 2022  we repeated our assessments of survival  growth  reproduction  and browse on our sentinel plants  and percent cover of associated vegetation.
#Text=Statistical Analysis\rWe used R version 3.6.1 (R Core Team�2019) to conduct all analyses.

#Text=We assessed effects of management (reference vs. herbicide treatment area)  time (days since planting)  and their interaction on survival of each species using Cox proportional Hazard models in package �coxme� (Therneau�2015).
#Text=Models included initial height at planting and average percent cover of surrounding vegetation as covariates.
#Text=We included random effects for unique plant individuals and area (treatment vs. reference) within sites to account for repeated measurements and experimental design.

#Text=We used general linear mixed models (GLMM)  package �glmmTMB� (Brooks et al�2017) to model measures of growth (height and leaf width)  time (days since planting)  and their interaction for each species individually.
#Text=We included initial size at planting and percent cover of surrounding vegetation as covariates.

#Text=We added random effects for area (treatment vs. reference) within site and plant individual and scaled all numeric parameters (initial height  cover of surrounding vegetation  and days since planting) to allow comparisons.
#Text=In the case of�O. sensibilis�growth models  we omitted one set of measurements (September 2019) where plants at northern sites had senesced.

#Text=In all models  we excluded observations where assigned treatment did not match the history of the planting area due to Global positioning System (GpS) error (n 2 individuals assigned �treatment� but not located in treated areas).
#Text=Herbicide treatments of�p. australis�at our sites (but not directly at our planting locations) were ongoing during our study  targeting remaining individuals.
#Text=To investigate whether length of treatment (duration in years) impacted survival and growth  we subset data to only individuals in treated plots.

#Text=We ran models with treatment length as a categorical variable (short-term: 1_4  years  and long-term: 5_8  years) interacting with time since planting and including initial height  cover of surrounding vegetation as covariates  with random effects for site and plant individual.
#Text=We scaled all numeric parameters (initial height  cover of surrounding vegetation  and days since planting).
#Text=After running models  we checked all model assumptions using package �DHARMa� (Hartig�2022).
#Text=We used package �corrplot� (Wie & Simko�2021) to check for correlation between our variables and did not detect any strong correlations ( �S1).
#Text=We observed a low to moderate correlation (  0.33) between number of years treated and vegetation cover  which we expected given site history.
#Text=We used the package �emmeans� (Lenth�2022) to estimate marginal means and make post hoc comparisons.
#Text=We reported an estimate +/-1  SE and considered�p  less than 0.05 as statistically significant.\r.Results.
#Text=After four growing seasons  we observed high variation in survival rates between species  reference  and treatment areas  and among sites (Table�1).
#Text=For example �Asclepias incarnatasurvival ranged from 5.3% (one surviving individual in 2022) in the treated area of Site 2 to 89% (17 individuals) in the reference area of Site 1.
#Text=For�Onoclea sensibilis  survival ranged from 14.3% (3) in the treatment area to 100% in the reference area at Site 2.
#Text=For�Spiraea alba  survival ranged from 9.5% (2) in the treated area of Site 4 to 76% (16) in the treated area of Site 1.
#Text=Averaged across sites �O. sensibilis�had the highest survival (65.3  +/-  3.7%; mean  +/-  SE)  followed by�A. incarnata�(50.9  +/-  4.7%)  and�S. alba�(40.1  +/-  3.8%) (Table�S1).
#Text=Table 1.
#Text=�Summary of predicted influence of treatment (compared to reference areas)  and treatment level (long-term compared to short-term) on each species survival  height  and leaf width.
#Text=Effects were estimated by models for each species and response variable pair  comparing treatment versus reference sites.
#Text=Blank cells represent nonsignificant effects  + represents positive     represents negative  and asterisks * represent interactions with time that are statistically significant.

#Text=Treatment\rTreatment level\r\rSurvival\rHeight\rLeaf width\rSurvival\rHeight\rLeaf width\rAsclepias incarnata\r\r+*\r+*\r\r\r\rOnoclea sensibilis\r\r\r\r�\r\r\rSpiraea alba\r�\r+*\r+*\r\r\r\rSurvival tended to be lower for all species in treatment areas; however  this was statistically significant for only one species:�S. alba�(Tables�S2�&�S3  �3).

#Text=Initial height at transplanting (estimate +/-1  SE:   0.02  +/-  0.01;�p  =  0.03) and percent cover (  0.02  +/-  0.01;�p  =  0.01)  but not treatment area (  0.52  +/-  0.33;�p  =  0.12)  significantly influenced�A. incarnata�survival  with individuals being more likely to survive when taller or in areas with higher vegetative cover (Table�S1).

#Text=For�O. sensibilis  vegetation cover (  0.02  +/-  0.98;�p  =  0.02) was the only predictor of survival  with increasing cover increasing the proportion of individuals surviving (Tables�S1�&�S3).

#Text=In our analysis of short- versus long-term treatments  however  we found a significant difference in likelihood of survival of�O. sensibilis�between treatment levels (0.94  +/-  2.57;�p  =  0.01).
#Text=Individuals in short-term treatment areas were significantly more likely to survive than those growing in long-term treatment areas (Tables�S4�&�S5;  �4).
#Text=Treatment duration (short- or long-term) did not significantly influence survival of�A. incarnata�or�S. alba(Tables�S4�&�S5).
#Text=Figure 3\r   \rKaplan_Meier curves of species survival over time  modeling treatment by species only.

#Text=Survival probability over a 4-year observation period of three different wetland species planted in reference and treated wetland plots;�n  =  19_21 plants per plot at three (Asclepias incarnata) and four (Onoclea sensibilis�and�Spiraea alba) sites in the Adirondacks.
#Text=Outputs do not account for random effects  total cover  or initial size.
#Text=Error bars omitted for clarity.
#Text=Figure 4\r   \rKaplan_Meier curves of species survival over time for the subset of individuals planted into treated areas.

#Text=Survival probability over a 4-year observation period of three different wetland species planted in treated wetland plots for short-term (<4  years) or long-term (>4  years);�n  =  19�21 plants per site; at three (Asclepias incarnata) and four (Onoclea sensibilis�and�Spiraea alba) sites in the Adirondacks.
#Text=Outputs do not account for random effects  total cover  or initial size.
#Text=Error bars omitted for clarity.

#Text=Over time �A. incarnata�and�S. alba�grew taller in treated areas than in untreated reference wetlands (time      treatment interaction;�A. incarnata:   9.98  +/-  2.79;�p  <  0.001;�S. alba:   10.49  +/-  1.38;�p  <  0.01;  �5).
#Text=Initial height at planting (A. incarnata: 7.46  +/-  1.64;�p  <  0.001;�S. alba: 3.57  +/-  1.24;�p  <  0.01) was correlated positively with height for both species (Tables�S3�&�S6).

#Text=For�O. sensibilis  vegetation cover (2.34  +/-  0.72;�p  <  0.01) was the only significant predictor of height  with plants growing larger in areas with increased cover (Tables�S3�&�S6). plant leaf width followed similar patterns to height  with�A. incarnata�and�S. alba�having the widest leaves in treatment areas  but only over time (time      treatment interaction;�A. incarnata:   0.25  +/-  0.08;�p  <  0.01;�S. alba:   0.25  +/-  0.05;�p  <  0.001;  �S2).

#Text=Individuals with wider leaves at the time of planting were more likely to have larger leaf widths for all three species  and for�O. sensibilisthis was the only significant predictor (Tables�S3�&�S7).
#Text=We did not find any significant differences in height or leaf width for surviving individuals in short- and long-term treatment areas for any species in our subset analyses (Tables�S8�&�S9).
#Text=Figure 5\r   \rHeight (cm) of�Spiraea alba �Onoclea sensibilis  and�Asclepias incarnata�in herbicide treated and reference wetlands over four growing seasons.

#Text=Data are predicted height of transplants (n  =  94�130 per species) at four sites from 2019 to 2022 with plot (treated or reference) within site and plant individual included as random effects in models.
#Text=Note differences in�y_axis scale.
#Text=For full set of model outputs  see Tables S2�and�S3.

#Text=Individuals from all three species became reproductive in the time frame of our study; however  reproduction was low across sites and treatment levels  with only 15 individuals reaching a reproductive stage.
#Text=In the 4  years of observation  12 individuals flowered in treated and three in reference areas.
#Text=Due to this low occurrence  we were not able to model reproduction.
#Text=We observed a limited incidence of herbivore browsing during the study  with 20 individuals being browsed a total of 22 times across all sites and species.
#Text=The bulk of browse observations were located at our two southern sites: Sites 1 and 2 (n  =  10 for both sites).
#Text=Only two�O. sensibilis�(mean  +/-  SE  0.4%  +/-  0.3)  seven�S. alba�(1.4%  +/-  0.5)  and 11�A. incarnata�(2.9%  +/-  0.9) were browsed.
#Text=Discussion.
#Text=Our study documented the existence of statistically significant  but ecologically limited legacy effects of�phragmites australis�and its management using herbicide.
#Text=At least for the species we used as sentinels  these legacy effects are not a major impediment to survival and plant growth.
#Text=For the three species we chose  almost half of our seedlings survived for over 4  years after planting.

#Text=Additional restoration efforts using plantings of propagated individuals for species that are missing in replacement plant communities after�p. australismanagement may be an important strategy for influencing the trajectory of replacement plant communities and preventing reinvasion patterns (Lindig-Cisneros & Zedler�2002; Reid et al�2009; Byun et al�2015).

#Text=Such restoration has rarely been done for�p. australis�after herbicide treatment  and repeated herbicide treatments seem to be needed in perpetuity  leading to a lack of long-term improvements in native species presence or abundance (Martin & Blossey�2013; Rohal et al�2019; Bonello & Judd�2020).
#Text=We found only limited support for our hypothesis that herbicide treatment and years of treatment would negatively impact seedling survival.
#Text=While seedling survival in treatment areas and areas with longer treatment history was consistently reduced for all species  this pattern was only statistically significant for�Spiraea alba.
#Text=Large site-to-site variation in survival rates is likely a major factor influencing our statistical analyses.
#Text=Similar site-specific factors (often hydrology) influencing native plant recovery have been identified to be of primary importance in other studies (Batzer & Baldwin�2012; Rohal et al�2019).

#Text=Utilizing a much greater number of sites may have allowed for more robust conclusions  but even the lowest survival rates for�Asclepias incarnata�and�Onoclea sensibilis�in treated areas were greater than 30%  a very robust survival rate allowing these species to reestablish after�p. australis�invasion and removal using herbicide treatments.
#Text=Their ultimate fate  or fate of other species we did not investigate  in treatment areas is likely influenced by the success of long-term suppression of�p. australis.

#Text=Whether replanting or reseeding can create an effective additional �biotic resistance� (Levine et al�2004; Byun et al�2015; Grace et al�2017) to�p. australis�reinvasion requires careful study designs  for example considering other stressors (deer  hydrology  negative soil feedback processes  etc.) and long-term investigations  but such studies  to the best of our knowledge  do not currently exist.
#Text=Contrary to our expectations  we found a positive impact of herbicide treatment on plant growth for surviving individuals of�S. alba�and�A. incarnata�and an interaction with time.
#Text=We consider it likely that this enhancement in plant growth was a function of reduced plant competition in treatment areas (Weidlich et al�2021).
#Text=Herbicide and other management can create open areas with a lower density of proximate plants (Ailstock et al�2001; Kettenring & Adams�2011; Judd & Francoeur�2019).
#Text=Surviving plants are likely able to take advantage of reduced competition and therefore increased resource availability  responding with improved growth in treatment areas over time.
#Text=However  while growth was enhanced  this came at a cost of decreased survival because an increase in cover of surrounding vegetation increased plant survival.

#Text=We do not consider exposure to natural enemies (deer  insects  diseases  etc.) an important factor in explaining reduced survival rates because we observed very limited evidence for such effects during our study period.

#Text=We also do not expect that variations in microsite conditions reported in other studies (MacMahon�1998; OBrien & Zedler�2006) can explain the patterns we observed because survival rates continued to decline over time.
#Text=If microsite conditions were unfavorable  we would expect rapid death after transplanting.

#Text=We cannot exclude the possibility for long-term legacy effects of�p. australis�itself due to changes in soil biota (Crocker et al�2017) or cumulative effects of herbicides and their metabolites to influence these patterns of survival and growth  but our results cannot offer certainty for any mechanism  not even after a 4-year study.

#Text=Wetland plant community succession is typically considered rapid  at least initially with recruitment from the seed bank (van der Valk�1981)  but few of our planted individuals became reproductive  and turn-over in wetlands may need to be evaluated on a decadal time scale  as in the case of biological control of purple loosestrife (Lythrum salicaria)  where return of plant diversity significantly increased only after a decade following initial insect releases (Endriss et al�2022 �2024) or tropical rainforest succession (Elsy et al�2023).

#Text=This long-term perspective will need to be embraced when evaluating effects of herbicide or other treatments to reduce negative impacts of�p. australis�in North American wetlands  but such perspectives are not part of the current portfolio of introduced species management or restoration (Weidlich et al�2020 �2021; Singh & Byun�2023).

#Text=However  we also need to caution that the success we saw in plant establishment is specific to the species we chose  which are not rare but common  and thus our results need to be confirmed using other species  and particularly in areas with a longer�p. australis�invasion history and where larger areas are treated.

#Text=The�p. australis�management in the Adirondacks (Quirion et al�2018) targets small incipient populations  and studies comparing larger treatment areas consistently report suppression of the target  but limited benefits for native species (Bonello & Judd�2020; Rohal et al�2023).

#Text=As the size of treatment areas increases  costs for treatment and replanting will also increase  but we argue that restoration efforts are needed and should be built into any introduced species control program from the beginning.

#Text=Measuring success in introduced species management requires an indication of the well-being achieved for native species and not just a measurement of the often temporary suppression of the target species. planting sentinel individuals and following their fate over time is a useful and relatively economic procedure for evaluating restoration success or of potential non-target effects of herbicide or other management techniques in introduced species management.
#Text=Our results offer encouragement to improving restoration efforts after�p. australis�is suppressed by herbicide treatments.
#Text=The general approach of allowing unassisted succession to proceed and rely on seed banks or other seed inputs has not delivered desired results for native plant species.

#Text=Reseeding and particularly replanting with desirable or rare species appears a worthwhile approach to increase the desired conservation benefits (van der Loop et al�2023; Deever et al�2024) of�p. australis�management.
#Text=Targeted suppression of�p. australis�with herbicide after initial abundance declines  as was the case in our study  does not appear to be an existential threat to revegetation efforts.
#Text=And the high survival rates of individuals we transplanted into the existing wetland matrix offer an approach to increase the diversity in wetlands.
